jelisawuzhere: It’s so amazing to know that I am far from the only one who dealt with something after also reading a good amount of comments. I was considered undesirable pretty much throughout my entire adolescence by my peers. The first time I was called cute/pretty by a black cis boy we were just a few months away from graduation. We ended up seeing each other for a few months over the summer, until we went off to different colleges. I didn’t focus on it then but he never called me his gf even though he very public went out with two white girls before me. I guess I was just so happy for the attention.

moonfaerieluna: That was the same experience I had so I guess guys don’t prefer me because they’re prejudice 💀
lauva26: Guys, I really suggest you to read the slave women experiences and history. Brings light to so many issues even today. Explains so much. Makes you cry like crazy.
another_bedouin_victorian_girl: Wow. I would just say don't care what any one that biased or racist thinks, but I know that won't change the prejudices that sustain systemic racism. I was at an African-Omani wedding a couple years ago, and I was with an Arab girl, and I was the only white girl, and it was the only time in my life I felt racism towards me from African women. But looking back, I get it, because I was on the groom's side, and the groom had broken an engagement to a darker woman (and he's dark too so I don't get his racism personally) and dude was marrying a whiter looking African woman. So people probably assumed my husband is racist or that I was married because I was lighter, and that would make me mad too. Thing is these women were painting themselves white, not being natural and not caring what idiot men think at all...so I kind of saw that as sustaining the prejudices against their own beauty🌹❤️. I told my husband a lot of my friends wanted to marry his friend (because he was handsome) but as soon as they found out he only wanted white girls, or light Arabs they were like, forget that, dude is ugly...I feel sorry for him. It is like he is ashamed of his heritage, and hurting women because of his own insecurities...and I wonder how he treats his darker children? 😕😔😢
teya.evans: people are allowed to have a preference, this sounds like a bad experience but you can’t be butthurt over the fact some guy chose another girl over you in 8TH GRADE
oscarjonssson1: Wtf this story is just a guy choosing one girl over the other you just made it into a racist thing when it’s obv not
purplesneeze: I just stumbled on this, which is odd because recently I have been struggling to understand and see my own inherent biases, and privileges. So thank you for putting your story out there for me to read, i still am struggling but I have another insight to use.
cnote.velly: Or we just know we gotta have that one white friend if tha coos come around
createloveinspire: Wow! This hits close to home. Thank you for sharing. I never comment on anything on Instagram and it might be pointless to share this. When I was in high school (2009-2013). I attended a predominantly Mexican and Mexican American school (there were other Latinx groups but it was very low). Many of the Latinx students were white passing or light skin and there were few indigenous or dark skin Latinx. I am what many Latinx like to say,“Morena” not light enough to be considered light skin or dark enough to be called dark skin but still had indigenous features. From 10th grade to 12th grade I was really into this white passing Latinx boy who was my friend. I tried to get him to like me through making him home cooked meals, getting his homework when he was sick (he would get sick a lot) and many other things. I tried asking him out several times but he would reject me. When I tried to move on from him, he would reeled me in by showing a lot of interest me and giving me compliments. He did this for the next 3 years of high school. I got tired of it in my senior year that I stopped talking to him, hanging out with him during lunch, and bringing his homework when he missed school. The following week (after I stopped talking to him), he got with the only white girl in the school. This was a huge blow to my self esteem because it reminded me that no matter what I did for him, was there for him, and knew his deepest secrets, he would never want me: a skinny weird girl with indigenous features. This affected me so much that once I graduated I was so scared of being with anyone thinking they wouldn’t want me.
cannabisforbreakfast: I never thought of the “WoC vs everyone” dynamic in terms of a shared power over. Thank you for this. It clicked. And desire as political— yes. 🙏🏼 you both @ashleighthelion + @ihartericka

earthmomma_mia: This must have been so tough for you to process. Thank you for sharing

amarinaart: I resonate from the middle ground. areandbeing: Which Bell Hooks? There are sooo many and all so similar. You words are inspiring, and healing ✨👁✨
kinfolkkollective: 😔😔😔😔 First of all, fuck him and Becky. Second, What I really need people to do is understand the words they use. If you “prefer” one to the other, it means you think one is better. So, yes, preference for non-Black partners is 100% anti-Blackness.
t_minus_gymtime: I get that that’s how you felt; but, it’s invariably curious to have you assess how he felt about his decision. He could have chosen the other girl for a plethora of reasons. It’s about how YOU handled that choice and make that a part of your narrative. That didn’t annihilate you as a person and you still exist as a human on this thing we call earth. I truly believe that people should take ownership of their own stories and build the life you want with the people you want, and who want, to be in it. People are all different and they desire/relate to different people for variant reasons. In no way does their decision on a romantic relationship make you a better/worse person; it just means that you won’t have a romantic narrative with that particular person. #justmytwocents #foodforthought #bewhoyouareunapologetically
daneneebean: Yup, like how much would black femmes be desired or put on a pedestal if they were marketed how white women/white cis bodies were? Would the flesh color crayon be a rich brown? Would clothing sizing be different? Would “blonde hair blue eyes” not be the default for so much?
gloriousandgolden: I had a similar experience happen to me in middle school, and I cried about it right there and then when he choose someone else. I didn’t know why then but I do now.

rachelisfearless: The fact that she/they has to put "don't defend whiteness" in her/their post is one of the root causes of this problem. This is a sad story. Sad for Erika. Sad for young black femmes who are still hearing this daily and who made it this way? Hmm? Us.
whatsda_t_lc: The story of a black femme in suburban Hell... thank you for telling this story. It mirrors my struggle with desirability- growing up in Springfield, Va... always wanting the Black boys to see me. Wanting the white boys to see me. Wanting someone to be out and gay lol. Never getting any of the above and being denied access to affection on a regular basis. It makes this phenomenon of cis dudes (white and black) now somehow thinking I’m beautiful, gorgeous, desirable. It’s a real mind fuck! We even called Black body’s refusal to date or interact with black girls, the West Springfield virus (the name of my HS) Bc it was just a prevalent way of life for us, but we realized it was a plague and that they were dumb and brainwashed.

thekymoliver: Every part of this mirrored countless experiences in my formative years, through to adulthood. I have an ache in my heart, every time a Black man tells me that they prefer white women or that “they don’t care about race” and I shouldn’t “take that black stuff too seriously”... My heart aches similarly when they have never chosen women like me before and then state that “there’s just something intriguing” about me, that I “seem so strong”, that I remind them of their *insert relative whom they do not desire* and it is “comforting”. It’s not about me not liking their choices. It is about the reasons (or lack thereof) BEHIND those choices... minor unpicking leads you down a murky path of misogynoir, anti-blackness and ancestral groaning... The pain of protecting someone, fighting for someone, choosing them over and over again, regardless of your wants and needs, despite you never being a thought in their mind - that is how this Black Woman feels on a soul level. This skin, this womb... It is a burden to bear. I am tired... I read this, and I am saddened that anyone would have to experience these things too. I was hoping, it was not anon.
